item.title: There's a difference between hot and cold sweat — and one tends to smell more distinctive
item.description: Cold sweat is known as psychological sweat, while hot sweat is often the body's response to physical exertion.

item.title: Could Donald Trump win the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize?
item.description: Leaders seeking to curry favour with Trump have been quick to talk up the US president's chances, but experts aren't so sure.

item.title: Trump says 'first phase' of Gaza peace deal reached; hostages to be released within days
item.description: Arab countries backing the plan say it must lead to eventual independence for a Palestinian state.

item.title: What we've learnt about the 'ISIS brides', as federal police anticipate more returns
item.description: The Australian Federal Police said the group, which has returned from Syria, was being monitored as part of an ongoing operation.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 October 2025
item.description: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: New workplace laws aim to remove extra pain burden on parents arising from stillbirth
item.description: Laws have been introduced into federal parliament to stop employers from scrapping leave entitlements when families face the tragedy of a stillbirth or death of their baby.

item.title: The common mortgage feature that could be leaving you 'worse off'
item.description: Mortgage offset accounts have helped many Australians wipe interest off their home loan. But they don't always offer a benefit.

item.title: Gaza peace deal market impacts & Gemini crypto exchange enters Australia
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Robert Talevski to see how the Gaza peace deal has impacted markets; and Ricardo takes a look at Australia's crypto regulatory space with Gemini's Saad Ahmed.

item.title: A Gaza peace deal signed; au revoir to yet another French PM; & Australia's new security alliance
item.description: Hamas and Israel sign up for Phase One of Trump's new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza. France's revolving door on its prime ministerial office takes another spin. Plus Australia and PNG sign on to an expanded alliance for regional cooperation. And how desperate for $5,000 are you? Take a job at a haunted hotel desperate?

item.title: 'It felt like home': Why generations of migrant Australians love the NPL
item.description: Once the lifeblood of migrant communities, suburban football clubs are back on the national stage for the Australian Championship.

item.title: What’s the Senate actually estimating? Ft. David Pocock
item.description: The first senate estimates of the 48th Parliament have arrived – where the Albanese Labor Government and representatives from the Australian Public Service and government agencies are quizzed for up to 14 hours a day about pretty much anything. It’s tedious, it’s long, but it’s all about accountability, and Independent Senator for the ACT David Pocock takes us behind the scenes. Plus Bob Katter has a suggestion for the footy off-season, and Andrew Hastie has left the Coalition front bench.

item.title: 'Safe beds save lives': Calls for urgent action to address rising number of homeless women
item.description: Australians are being urged to recognise the link between domestic violence and homelessness, as more women face sleeping rough.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 October 2025
item.description: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Tsunami threat passes after powerful earthquake strikes Philippines
item.description: A tsunami alert for the Philippines, Palau and Indonesia has been lifted following a magnitude 7.4 earthquake south of the Philippines.

item.title: How a 'deeply embedded' part of Australian culture could change forever
item.description: Young Australians are leading this emerging generational shift, according to a new study.

item.title: The looming Europe travel change that will affect Australians
item.description: New personal data collection rules are about to come into effect in Europe's Schengen area. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Silver at highest since 1980 & how markets are reacting to Gaza peace deal
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Zoran Kresovic from Blueberry Markets about the day's market action, including how investors are feeling following the potential Gaza peace deal, the future for gold and the outlook for silver, which hit a near 45 year high.

item.title: Saving money and packing 'go bags': How Australians in the US are preparing for the worst
item.description: With changes to visas and growing scrutiny of foreign nationals, Australians in the US say they feel uncertain about their futures.

item.title: Australia's potato capital is facing a threat never-before-seen in the country
item.description: With eradication off the table, Australia is looking to New Zealand for lessons on how to manage potato mop top virus as planting begins in Tasmania.

item.title: Trump hikes tariffs on China by extra 100 per cent, threatens to cancel talks with Xi Jinping
item.description: There was no immediate reaction from Beijing after Trump said China should not "be allowed to hold the world 'captive'".

item.title: Three dead as light plane crashes just after take-off near Wollongong
item.description: Three people have been killed in a light plane crash shortly after take-off, in what first responders have described as a "gruesome" scene.

item.title: Clean-up begins in Philippines after at least eight killed in twin earthquakes
item.description: Some residents in Mindanao slept outdoors in fear of aftershocks after 7.4 and 6.7-magnitude earthquakes struck off the coast on Friday.

item.title: Casper takes a drug that helps him grow. But the treatment is controversial
item.description: A controversial drug Australia had a key role in developing continues to bring hope - and frustration – for the short-statured community.

item.title: Not just magpies: The other birds swooping you this season — and why they do it
item.description: Magpies may have perfected the art of swooping, but they're not the only Australian bird diving on unsuspecting humans this spring.

item.title: California sends ultraprocessed school meals to the sin bin
item.description: California is to phase out certain ultraprocessed foods from school meals over the next decade under a first-in-the-nation law signed by Governor Gavin Newsom. Schools will have to start removing those foods from their menus by July 2029, and districts will be barred from selling them for breakfast or lunch by July 2035.

item.title: Lostprophets singer Ian Watkins dies in prison attack
item.description: Lostprophets singer Ian Watkins was sentenced to 29 years in prison for child abuse in 2013.

item.title: Diane Keaton, star of Annie Hall and The Godfather, dies at 79
item.description: Diane Keaton, the Oscar-winning star of Annie Hall, The Godfather films and Father of the Bride, has died at the age of 79.

item.title: I asked a mortgage broker what median first home buyers can get with a 5% deposit (not much)
item.description: First home buyers can get into the housing market with a 5 per cent deposit - but are there hidden pitfalls they may not be aware of? We asked an expert to crunch the numbers.

item.title: 'I felt alone': Inside the 'invisible' loss one in three Australian women endure
item.description: Organisations that help women through miscarriages are looking forward to seeing a national pregnancy loss register to address what they say is an invisibility around the true scale of the issue.

item.title: The miscarriage data gap and 'invisible loss' leaving Australian women behind
item.description: A new report is calling for a national database on miscarriage to address ongoing invisibility around miscarriage and early pregnancy loss in Australia, particularly for First Nations women and in rural and regional communities. This comes as the government announced a $9.5 million funding package in May last year to improve awareness and support for early pregnancy loss.

item.title: Donald Trump softens tone on China after tariff tensions flare
item.description: Trump has taken a less confrontational approach in his latest social media post on trade tensions with China.

item.title: 'An all-time low': Why are Afghanistan and Pakistan fighting along their border?
item.description: Pakistan has accused Afghanistan of sheltering militants behind a surge in attacks on its soil.

item.title: Dozens killed as Pakistan–Afghanistan border clashes escalate
item.description: Dozens of fighters have been killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. Tensions have risen after Pakistan demanded the Taliban take action against militants who have stepped up attacks in Pakistan, saying they operate from bases in Afghanistan. The Taliban denies that Pakistani militants are present on its soil.

item.title: Has your Qantas data been leaked? Here's what you can do
item.description: A cybersecurity expert has warned scammers will employ both immediate and "long game" strategies to use the stolen data.

item.title: The changes to your superannuation in Treasurer Jim Chalmers' surprise announcement
item.description: The government has responded to ongoing criticism, announcing half a dozen changes to the tax reforms they brought to the 2022 election.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 13 October
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: New super changes for low income earners and high balances & how geopolitics is impacting markets
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Daniel Martin from Alvia Asset Partners about the day's market news including the impact of geopolitics including the holding ceasefire in Gaza; plus hear from Treasurer Jim Chalmers as he addresses changes to superannuation.

item.title: AFP investigates Lidia Thorpe's 'burn down Parliament House' remarks
item.description: Thorpe's comments sparked a political firestorm, with Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke urging leaders to avoid inflaming community tensions.

item.title: 'Eating mostly brown food': The 'devastating' juggle faced by a rising number of Australians
item.description: With one in seven Australians living below the poverty line, researchers and advocates say that COVID-era universal income is the solution.

item.title: ‘Historic exchange’: all Israeli hostages freed as Gaza peace talks continue
item.description: All 20 surviving Israeli hostages have been released from Hamas captivity in Gaza in a historic exchange as part of the first phase of a Gaza peace plan. And nearly 2000 Palestinians have also been freed from Israeli prisons, with the majority headed back to the war-ravaged Palestinian enclave. United States President Donald Trump has claimed the Israel-Hamas war is over, but negotiations are set to continue in Egypt with long-term peace still far from secure.

item.title: The new threat to Australia's potato industry - what is it and how can we deal with it?
item.description: Of all Australian states, Tasmania is the biggest producer of potatoes, and a lot of what's grown here goes into potato products you would know well – hot chips, hash browns and wedges among them. But a new virus detected in recent months is causing concern. Growers are optimistic it can be managed, stressing it doesn't pose a risk to human health.

item.title: 'Historic dawn': Key takeaways from Trump's speech at the Israeli parliament
item.description: Trump announced a new era of peace, as Hamas freed the remaining hostages and Israel released nearly 2,000 prisoners and detainees.

item.title: 'I don't have words': Cape Verde erupts in celebration after historic World Cup qualification
item.description: The island nation is set to become one of the smallest countries to participate in football's showpiece event.

item.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
item.description: A large white coral reef containing important species and fossil traces has been discovered at a depth of more than 500 metres in the Gulf of Naples, in a rare discovery for the Mediterranean. But a new report suggests reefs like this might already be in danger, with global warming crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected and the world's coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off. It marks what scientists are describing as the first tipping point in climate-driven ecosystem collapse.

item.title: Middle East peace deal signed; so where to from here?
item.description: World leaders have signed a historic Middle East deal at a summit in Egypt. It comes hours after Israel and Hamas exchanged detainees and hostages. Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinians from Israeli prisons, and Gaza released the surviving Israeli hostages after two years in captivity.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 14 October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Hamas' next move is unknown, but one person may 'hold the key' to a lasting peace in Gaza
item.description: The first phase of a deeply complex peace process has begun. So what happens next?

item.title: What are rare earths, and why are the share prices of companies mining them surging?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Kai Chen from MPC Markets about the rise on rare earths along with the rest of the day's sharemarket action.

item.title: 'Mystified': Concern for thousands in Australia after Venezuela's surprise move
item.description: The closure of Venezuela's embassy in Canberra follows the Nobel Peace Prize being awarded to Venezuela's opposition leader over the weekend. But are the two related?

item.title: Warning Australia faces 'looming period of risk' as it awaits nuclear submarines
item.description: As Australia awaits nuclear-powered submarines, a strategic policy think tank warns we're sitting vulnerable to potential threats.

item.title: Victorian government debates ground-breaking Treaty Bill
item.description: The Victorian Government is debating a historic Statewide Treaty Bill, establishing Australia's first ever Treaty agreement between a state government and First Peoples in Victoria. If signed into law, the Treaty Bill will forge a path forward for First Peoples in Victoria to negotiate and influence the policy that affects community.

item.title: Military seizes power in Madagascar after president flees amid youth protests
item.description: Gen Z-driven demonstrations erupted last month over water and power shortages, quickly escalating into an uprising over broader grievances.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 15 October
item.description: A daily five-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Australian passport power revealed, as the US and UK hit record lows
item.description: For the first time in 20 years, the United States' passport has fallen from the top ten most powerful in the world.

item.title: Socceroos' undefeated streak ends with loss to US
item.description: The Socceroos have already qualified for the World Cup, with coach Tony Popovic hoping new players "surprise" him ahead of the finals.

item.title: Israel and Hamas both accused of not keeping cease fire agreement
item.description: Hamas has returned more bodies of Israeli hostages to the International Committee of the Red Cross in Gaza. Questions remain over sustainable peace in the Middle East, with uncertainty about how to resolve sticking points in Donald Trump's 20-point plan.

item.title: These Sydneysiders watched as the hostage-detainee swap played out. Then came a call
item.description: Palestinian and Jewish Australians describe their emotional journey watching the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire.

item.title: Kathryn lost her banking job to a chatbot. She just confronted her CBA bosses
item.description: Former Commonwealth Bank employee Kathryn Sullivan spent years teaching the bank's "Bumblebee" chatbot how to respond to customers.

item.title: 'La Crise': French politics stumbles from crisis to crisis
item.description: The Eurozone's second-largest economy is battling a deep political crisis. It all started when French President Emmanuel Macron called snap elections last year in an attempt to consolidate his power. Instead, they resulted in a hung parliament and gains for the far right. Now, France’s sixth prime minister in under two years has been forced to abandon one of the president’s key achievements just to hold his government together.

item.title: What record low fertility rates mean for our economy & gold hits another record
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with McCrindle Social Researcher Ashley Fell about thegrowing trend for Australians to have fewer kids, and later in life; plus Luke Laretive from Seneca Financial Services looks through the day's sharemarket moves including what he is telling his clients.

item.title: The 'confluence of crises' driving Australia's record-low fertility rate
item.description: Australia's birth rate is declining — but researchers say it's "not about selfishness".

item.title: Labor criticised over worker visa rule backflip that could affect thousands
item.description: Tens of thousands of people from the Pacific and East Timor currently work in Australia under the PALM scheme.

item.title: NSW hits 'grim milestone' with First Nations deaths in custody reaching record levels
item.description: The New South Wales coroner says the state has hit a grim milestone with First Nations deaths in custody reaching record levels. 12 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have died in custody in the state this year, the highest number ever recorded in a single year. The distressing figures have prompted the state coroner to issue a rare public statement, condemning the deaths and vowing to investigate each one independently and thoroughly.

item.title: Australia's rainforests are now adding to carbon emissions, scientists say
item.description: A new study has found Queensland's tropical rainforests emit more carbon than they absorb, raising concerns for Australia's climate targets.

item.title: Young people feel much more disconnected than boomers in Australia. Why?
item.description: Social isolation and economic disadvantage are partly responsible for declining rates in national belonging, a new study suggests.

item.title: Hamas says it can't retrieve more bodies, as first hostage funerals start in Israel
item.description: Israel confirmed it had received the coffins of two more deceased hostages and was transporting them to a facility for identification.

item.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
item.description: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

item.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
item.description: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

item.title: Is your job burning you out? Experts say better boundaries and workplace connections can help
item.description: Despite a growing awareness around mental health, research shows burnout in the workplace is still a major challenge. Experts say without proper training and healthy boundaries in the workplace, more and more Australians will consider leaving their jobs in the next year.

item.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan announce temporary ceasefire following border clashes
item.description: The truce follows accusations of cross-border attacks and civilian casualties, which have strained relations between the two neighbours.

item.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan announce temporary ceasefire following border clashes
item.description: The truce follows accusations of cross-border attacks and civilian casualties, which have strained relations between the two neighbours.

item.title: Trump confirms he authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela
item.description: Donald Trump said he was "looking at land now" after recently targeting alleged drug smuggling boats from Venezuela by sea.

item.title: Hamas-Israel ceasefire holds - but only just
item.description: Two more bodies of deceased hostages have been handed over to the Red Cross by Hamas, following Israel's accusation that the militant group were failing to abide by the terms of the ceasefire deal. Aid is continuing to roll into Gaza despite threats from Israel that they would cut supplies and close border crossings. But there are heightened concerns for the fragile ceasefire, amid reports US President Donald Trump is considering allowing Israel to resume its military activities.

item.title: Germany, NATO pledge billions in new Ukraine aid as Russia reels from fuel strikes
item.description: Germany and NATO allies have pledged billions in new aid to Ukraine as the war nears its fourth winter, with Kyiv urging urgent air-defence support amid a sharp drop in foreign assistance. Meanwhile, Russia is grappling with fuel shortages following Ukrainian strikes, as President Donald Trump renews his criticism of Vladimir Putin over the prolonged conflict and Russia’s faltering economy.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 16 October
item.description: A daily five-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Army vehicle fleet grounded after soldier killed during training rollover in Queensland
item.description: The soldier died after the M113 armoured personnel carrier he was travelling in rolled west of Townsville about 6.30pm on Wednesday.

item.title: Government could make offshore skills change to solve 'wicked' problem
item.description: Proposed tweaks to the skilled migration pathway could ensure migrants arrive job-ready.

item.title: 'Degraded and uneasy': Incarcerated trans women push back on NT prison ban proposal
item.description: Trans women prisoners are most at risk of violence, advocates say, hitting back at the NT chief minister's recent claims.

item.title: Yeah, nah: Australians report a drop in their sense of belonging
item.description: Australians' sense of belonging has been declining over time. That's the major finding from this year's social cohesion report, from the Scanlon Foundation Research Institute. But while the report suggests there is ongoing strain in peoples' sense of belonging, trust, and identity, the Foundation remains optimistic, saying most Australians still report happiness and a strong sense of community.

item.title: ASX hits record as jobless rate rises to 4.5%
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Brycki from Stockspot while Stephanie Youseff talks with Alex Joiner from IFM Investors about the rise in the unemployment rate to a near four year high, what it means for interest rates and why the sharemarket hit a record as a result.

item.title: The great divide: Australians reach a 'difficult' new high
item.description: Some say the numbers show life is getting harder, while others argue the picture isn’t as "dire" as it seems.

item.title: SPECIAL EPISODE: Inside the Gaza ceasefire: hostages, prisoners & a negotiator
item.description: Israeli hostages have been released and Palestinians prisoners freed, but is the Trump-brokered truce a turning point or just a timeout? This in-depth episode explores the deal, the delivery of aid, and the future of Gaza.

item.title: Israel delays reopening of crucial Gaza border, rules out aid transfers
item.description: A key border crossing between Gaza and Egypt will remain closed, dashing hopes it would quickly open under a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: Melbourne’s weekly pro-Palestinian protests to pause after Gaza ceasefire
item.description: Organisers say Sunday rallies outside the state library will be halted, a move which was reportedly welcomed by Melbourne's lord mayor.

item.title: 'Bombs have stopped, but threats remain': The 'absolute catastrophe' inside Gaza
item.description: Humanitarian groups call for all Gaza crossings to open so more aid can enter, warning efforts depend on sustaining the fragile ceasefire.

item.title: Australia’s rental affordability 'myth' that doesn’t match reality
item.description: Workers in critical sectors are frequently locked out of affordable housing — and not just in capital cities, a new report says.

item.title: Australia’s rental affordability 'myth' that doesn’t match reality
item.description: Workers in critical sectors are frequently locked out of affordable housing — and not just in capital cities, a new report says.

item.title: Trump says he will meet Putin to discuss Ukraine war after 'great progress' in call
item.description: Donald Trump said he and Vladimir Putin would meet to discuss if they can bring the "inglorious" war to an end.

item.title: Government considering offshore recognition of migrant skills
item.description: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says the government is working on the possibility of an offshore recognition of skills. He says this will help save time and money for skilled migrants looking to move to Australia. In his address the Press Club in Canberra Mr Burke also flagged changes to inactive bank accounts to combat money laundering.

item.title: What this week's surprise unemployment data could mean for your mortgage repayments
item.description: Australia's jobless rate has hit a near four-year high, raising speculation it could trigger another rate cut by the Reserve Bank.

item.title: Vatican report says clergy sex abuse victims need reparations and tangible sanctions to heal
item.description: An internal Vatican report has delivered scathing criticism of the Catholic Church's handling of decades of allegations of sexual abuse from around the world. It's calling for financial reparations and sanctions for abusers and their enablers. AND A WARNING THAT THE CONTENT OF THIS STORY MAY BE DISTRESSING FOR SOME LISTENERS

item.title: Hundreds of claims a day: Are these Australia's most dangerous jobs?
item.description: More than 180 workers died from traumatic injuries while working in Australia last year, according to Safe Work Australia.

item.title: Australian military 'contingency planning' for possible Gaza troop deployment
item.description: A temporary international stabilisation force is a vital element of Donald Trump's 20-point peace plan for Gaza.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 October
item.description: A daily five-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Fears grow over truce's fragility amid concerns around hostages bodies, aid
item.description: Israel is pressing Hamas to honour the ceasefire agreement and return the bodies of hostages still held in Gaza. This comes as satellite images show limited aid convoys entering the enclave through Kerem Shalom, while displaced Palestinians in Khan Younis endure worsening living conditions amid shortages of food, fuel, and clean water. With more than 67,900 Palestinians killed since 2023 and uncertainty over Rafah’s reopening, fears are growing that the fragile truce could collapse.

item.title: KISS founding member and lead guitarist Ace Frehley dies at 74
item.description: Ace Frehley, founding member of the glam rock band KISS, has died at 74 after complications following a recent fall.

item.title: The quiet creep that's making Australian banking less 'inclusive and accessible'
item.description: A decline in face-to-face banking services and cash facilities is harming some Australians more than others, advocates say.

item.title: Gold price warning as some traditional buyers tap out at record levels
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Oreana Private Wealth Chief Investment Officer Isaac Poole in Asia, who says some traditional gold buyers are tapping out of the market at current record levels, plus a look at the day's market action.

item.title: How Donald Trump became a hero in Israel
item.description: The release of Israeli hostages saw Donald Trump hailed as a hero to the Jewish people this week. This is why he's getting all the credit.

item.title: Champion of champions: Remembering Dr Charles Perkins 25 years after his death
item.description: This weekend marks 25 years since the passing of Arrernte and Kalkadoon leader Dr Charles Perkins.

item.title: Long-lost diary tells a personal story of China's involvement in D-Day
item.description: A long-lost diary from a Chinese war veteran has been discovered, detailing the participation of China's participation in D-Day. The 80-page diary was discovered in an abandoned Hong Kong flat, and details Lam Ping Yu's brush with death during the world's largest-ever sea, land and air armada on D Day during World War Two.

item.title: Prince Andrew renounces title amid renewed scrutiny over Epstein ties
item.description: The move comes after new claims surfaced in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir detailing Andrew's alleged involvement with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Prince Andrew renounces title amid renewed scrutiny over Epstein ties
item.description: The move comes after new claims surfaced in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir detailing Andrew's alleged involvement with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Barking bad: The ruff road to recovery
item.description: Dogs can become so attached to particular toys that they display behaviour that would be associated with addiction in humans. Researchers say when the dogs were deprived of their toys in the study, they became so fixated on what they'd lost that their blood pressure increased and they ignored everything else.

item.title: 'Get the war over': Trump backs away from giving long-range missiles to Ukraine
item.description: Zelenskyy came to Washington after weeks of calls for Tomahawk missiles, hoping to capitalise on Trump's growing frustration with Putin.

item.title: 'Get the war over': Trump backs away from giving long-range missiles to Ukraine
item.description: Zelenskyy came to Washington after weeks of calls for Tomahawk missiles, hoping to capitalise on Trump's growing frustration with Putin.

item.title: Remains of another Israeli hostage in Gaza handed over by Hamas
item.description: Israel says it has received nine of 28 bodies held in Gaza, with Hamas saying it needed heavy machinery and excavating equipment to speed up the process.

item.title: Albanese will finally meet Trump. Here’s how it went for other leaders
item.description: Since Trump's return to the presidency, over 270 days have passed without an official meeting between Albanese and Trump.

item.title: 'Irreparably broken': Barnaby Joyce to quit Nationals, won't contest seat at next election
item.description: Reports the firebrand MP plans to defect to One Nation are not yet confirmed, but his options have been kept open.

item.title: 'Approach with caution': A warning to the public as gold and silver prices skyrocket
item.description: While the price of gold has kept skyrocketing, prices "can go down and stay down for a very long period of time", an expert warns.

item.title: AI 'supercharging' bullying, minister warns, as $10 million tipped into new school plan
item.description: Artificial intelligence has led to a "terrifying" new type of bullying, the education minister has warned.

item.title: Morning News Bulletin 19 October 2025
item.description: Israel reportedly kills 11 members of one family in airstrike on Gaza city; fallout after Barnaby Joyce quits the Nationals; Ange Postecoglou sacked as Nottingham Forest manager.

item.title: Could your dog be an addict? Scientists think so
item.description: Does your dog seem to really, really love playing with a certain toy? It may be something more than harmless fun.

item.title: How 'anti-foreign worker sentiment' is snuffing out the dreams of Australians in the US
item.description: Rapid political change has shattered the dreams of some Australians who were looking to work or study in the US.

item.title: When is Diwali and what does the festival celebrate?
item.description: The global festival of lights lasts five days.

item.title: How caring in language can prevent elderly falls
item.description: In Australia, around one in four people aged over 65 experiences at least one fall each year and it is the leading cause of injury, hospitalisation, and death among older Australians. Preventing falls isn’t simple, especially when language stands in the way of awareness. But in Perth, two Chinese university students are turning that challenge into change, using their culture and compassion to protect some of those most vulnerable.

item.title: A rich cultural heritage celebrated in lights: Diwali
item.description: Diwali is the biggest festival in India and many South Asian countries, marking the victory of good over evil and the triumph of light over darkness. It is celebrated by more than a billion people around the world, including diaspora communities in Australia.

item.title: Two more hostage bodies handed over as Netanyahu says war not over until Hamas disarms
item.description: Israel says the Rafah border crossing will remain closed as Hamas has been too slow to hand over the bodies of deceased hostages.

item.title: Nationals leader says he'd like Barnaby Joyce to stay with the party
item.description: Joyce has signalled his intention to leave the National Party, and the move has prompted speculation he could defect to One Nation.

item.title: An 'entirely unpredictable' Albanese-Trump meeting wouldn't harm relations, minister says
item.description: A minister has downplayed the risk of Donald Trump dressing down Anthony Albanese when the two leaders come face-to-face.

item.title: Midday News Bulletin 19 October 2025
item.description: The Nationals leader urges Barnaby Joyce to stay with the party; the UN aid chief says mobilising aid in Gaza is a massive task; Australian Jack Miller set to compete in the Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix.

item.title: Minister 'concerned' at setting migration targets as protesters march across the country
item.description: In Melbourne, police used pepper spray and flash distraction devices as they sought to keep the rival rallies separated.

item.title: Evening News Bulletin 19 October 2025
item.description: Clashes in Melbourne as competing protests face off across the country again, No Kings' demonstrations draw large crowds across the US, Mollie O'Callaghan sets a swimming world record.

item.title: Is the government's new plan to combat bullying fair, and what's missing from it?
item.description: Amid ongoing community concerns about the devastating impacts of bullying, how does the government's new plan stack up?

item.title: Is the government's new plan to combat bullying fair, and what's missing from it?
item.description: Amid ongoing community concerns about the devastating impacts of bullying, how does the government's new plan stack up?

item.title: 'We matter, we belong': This year Diwali carries new meaning for Indian Australians
item.description: Amid political tension, Diwali offers Indian Australians a moment to celebrate — and quietly affirm they belong.

item.title: Are you experiencing burnout? Here are the signs — and what can be done
item.description: Despite growing awareness around mental health in the workplace, research suggests burnout is getting worse in Australia.

item.title: I had anti-women views as a teenager. Now I cringe at the words we used
item.description: Jamie's changed now, but as a teen he had problematic views largely informed by early YouTube videos and online gaming, he says.

item.title: What to expect from Albanese's meeting with Trump, as he arrives in the US
item.description: Only time will tell if these two very different personalities from opposite sides of the political spectrum will be able to gel.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire to resume after Israeli strikes kill at least 26
item.description: Israel said it carried out the strikes after an earlier attack killed two of its soldiers, in what is the most serious test yet of the US-brokered truce.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire to resume after Israeli strikes kill at least 26
item.description: Israel said it carried out the strikes after an earlier attack killed two of its soldiers, in what is the most serious test yet of the US-brokered truce.

item.title: Israel strikes Gaza in major test of ceasefire | Morning News Bulletin 20 October 2025
item.description: Israel says air strikes and artillery fire in southern Gaza are in response to Hamas violations of the ceasefire; Victoria Police says it expects to make more arrests over weekend protests; and in sport, Australia's triathlete Matt Hauser wins a world triathlon title in Wollongong.

item.title: 'No violence, very professional': What we know about the Louvre jewellery heist
item.description: Masked robbers broke into the Paris museum using a crane and angle grinders to steal French crown jewels worth tens of millions of dollars.

item.title: Barnaby Joyce reveals he spoke with Pauline Hanson amid National Party split plans
item.description: The Nationals MP confirmed he had briefly spoken with One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, but didn't detail the conversation.

item.title: Sussan Ley announces plan to give Australians income tax cuts, without details or costings
item.description: The Coalition is planning tax cuts and policy reform in the lead-up to the next election, but details are scarce.

item.title: Trump, Albanese to meet in coming hours | Midday News Bulletin 20 October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Anthony Albanese to meet with Donald Trump over AUKUS and trade, the Puk Puk defence treaty with PNG is a step closer to being implemented. And in Formula One, Max Verstappen wins the US Grand Prix.

item.title: Police union boss likens Melbourne protest to Northern Ireland in the 1970s
item.description: Premier Jacinta Allan blamed a "very small number" of counter-protesters for the violence and said they deserved to face "serious consequences".

item.title: 'How' not 'who' the question after Louvre crown jewels smash and grab
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron says everything is being done to catch the people behind a spectacular jewel heist at the Louvre, the latest in a series of museum robberies. After the brazen theft of some of France's crown jewels in broad daylight, staff and union representatives say not enough has been done to guard the objects and people at one of the world's most famous galleries.

item.title: Two people dead after plane slides off runway and into sea in Hong Kong
item.description: The aircraft deviated from the north runway and slid into the sea, Hong Kong's Civil Aviation Department said.

item.title: Big bills, no seat: Some of the federal election's big spenders didn't actually win
item.description: Independent candidates received and spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to get elected to federal parliament — some unsuccessfully.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 20 October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Promising signs for AUKUS ahead of meeting | Evening News Bulletin 20 October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, signs AUKUS is assured, hours before the Prime Minister meets with Donald Trump, dozens of deaths reported in Israeli strikes on Gaza, with allegations of ceasefire breaches on both sides. And in sport, India backs Kohli to bounce back from poor performance in the last ODI.

item.title: Diwali shines a light on culture for Australian family in Gujarat
item.description: This week, more than a billion people around the world are celebrating Diwali, the religious festival celebrating the victory of light over darkness. It's an important time for Australia’s South Asian communities. But one family is going a step further, travelling to India for the occasion. SBS caught up with them in Gujarat, on India’s west coast.

item.title: 'Concerning' or a sign of 'good things'? What Australia's flu record means
item.description: There's been a 10 per cent increase in flu rates compared to last year, with doctors sounding the alarm over vaccine hesitancy.

item.title: What are rare earth minerals and why is Donald Trump interested in Australia's supply?
item.description: They're used in electric vehicles, weapons and green energy, but what actually are rare earths?

item.title: PM's balancing act ahead of US talks as China's economy expands by 4.8%
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is in the US meeting President Donald Trump but has a delicate balancing act considering how important China is to Australia. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP and David Scutt from Forex.com to find out what it means for Australia and the market reaction.

item.title: More arrests likely after Melbourne immigration protests turn violent
item.description: Safety on the streets of Melbourne has been brought into question after protesters pelted police with rocks and bottles filled with broken glass at a weekend protest. Victoria Police expect to make more arrests after two officers were injured during the demonstrations on Sunday.

item.title: As an ex-Olympian, I felt embarrassed about my body. Here's how I regained my pride
item.description: For years, Olympic swimmer Joanna Fargus tried to hide her success as an athlete because she felt ashamed about her weight.

item.title: Global Amazon outage affects hundreds of platforms | Morning News Bulletin 21 October 2025
item.description: A major global outage affects Amazon, disrupting hundreds of platforms; Donald Trump and Anthony Albanese meet at the White House and sign a deal on critical minerals; and in football, a first World Cup win for Morocco.

item.title: Here's what we know so far about Trump and Albanese's $13 billion rare earths deal
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese signed a rare earth minerals deal in Washington, stating it goes beyond "just digging things up".

item.title: Amazon says AWS cloud services back to normal after massive outage
item.description: The disruption affected streaming platforms including Amazon's Prime Video and Disney+, as well as apps Airbnb, Snapchat and Duolingo.

item.title: Amazon says AWS cloud services back to normal after massive outage
item.description: The disruption affected streaming platforms including Amazon's Prime Video and Disney+, as well as apps Airbnb, Snapchat and Duolingo.

item.title: Hamas warned 'to behave', as remains of another returned Israeli hostage identified
item.description: US President Donald Trump has sent a warning to Hamas, after the group handed over the remains of one more Israeli hostage.

item.title: Hamas warned 'to behave', as remains of another returned Israeli hostage identified
item.description: US President Donald Trump has sent a warning to Hamas, after the group handed over the remains of one more Israeli hostage.

item.title: 'Friends', but with tariffs: Five key things to know from the Trump-Albanese meeting
item.description: An awkward moment between Donald Trump and Kevin Rudd failed to derail the US president's first meeting with "friend" Anthony Albanese.

item.title: 'Very popular': Albanese's glow sends an important message to China
item.description: Donald Trump's meeting with Anthony Albanese comes ahead of a hotly anticipated one-on-one with Xi Jinping.

item.title: 'Back him or sack him': Ley takes aim at Rudd, criticises PM's Trump tariff 'failure'
item.description: Sussan Ley has doubled down on calls to dismiss ambassador Kevin Rudd, despite reports Donald Trump has accepted his apology.

item.title: 'Back him or sack him': Ley takes aim at Rudd, criticises PM's Trump tariff 'failure'
item.description: Sussan Ley has doubled down on calls to dismiss ambassador Kevin Rudd, despite reports Donald Trump has accepted his apology.

item.title: US envoys arrive in Israel to shore up ceasefire | Midday News Bulletin 21 October 2025
item.description: The US sends its advisers to Israel as Gaza ceasefire threatened; Opposition leader Sussan Ley calls on Kevin Rudd to resign; And in sport, a joint bid to host the 2031 Women's World Cup.

item.title: Your viewing guide to the Orionids meteor shower as it reaches its peak
item.description: Australia will witness its "fourth best" meteor shower of the year on Wednesday morning. Here's what you can expect.

item.title: More sunscreens have been recalled. Is yours among them?
item.description: Two more sunscreens are off the shelves, as parts of Australia brace for a week of hot temperatures.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 21 October 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Australia and China trade accusations after South China Sea flare incident
item.description: The potential consequences of a flare striking a plane are severe, an expert has said.

item.title: US officials work to preserve Gaza ceasefire
item.description: Diplomatic efforts have intensified in the Middle East as the United States works to preserve the fragile Gaza ceasefire following a weekend of renewed violence. The truce, part of US President Donald Trump’s multi-phase Gaza plan, was shaken after a Palestinian attack killed two Israeli soldiers, triggering Israeli airstrikes that left dozens dead.

item.title: The growing number of Australians adopting this risky travel trend
item.description: The government places this "expectation" on all Australians travelling overseas, yet a growing number aren't heeding the advice.

item.title: Japan set to welcome first female PM following coalition deal | Evening News Bulletin 21 October 2025
item.description: Japan set to welcome first female PM following coalition deal; Defence Minister says jobs expected to flow from AUKUS defence agreement; And in AFL, coaches named ahead of first State of Origin game in almost 27 years.

item.title: 'Broke half the internet': Amazon cloud outage lasts 15 hours, triggering global chaos
item.description: A massive internet outage has taken out thousands of websites, apps and services globally. The technical fault originated with U-S data centres operated by Amazon Web Services, which controls 30 per cent of the world's cloud computing market that underpins web-based services like apps and websites.

item.title: Deals signed as Trump and Albanese meet; but what are the wider implications?
item.description: In a historic meeting between Donald Trump and Anthony Albanese, the AUKUS agreement remained unchanged as the two leaders unveiled a multi-billion-dollar critical minerals deal to secure supply chains and reduce reliance on China. The agreement involves major US investment in Australian mining and processing projects, but has sparked criticism over fears it could give the US too much control over Australia’s resources and sovereignty.

item.title: Rare earths deal boosts some mining shares as ASX hits record
item.description: The Australian sharemarket hit a record high for a second time in a week as the US and Australia strike a rare earths supply deal, but it was BHP that was a real stand out today. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Catherine Allfrey from Wavestone Capital to find out if the sector is worth the hype and what else is driving investors.

item.title: Rare earth minerals deal declared 'a triumph'
item.description: Australia's newly sealed critical minerals deal with the United States has sent the share market skyrocketing. The industry and investors are responding to billions of dollars in new investment aimed at disrupting China's dominance over global rare earths supply chains.

item.title: The $42 billion 'disaster penalty' hitting these Australian homeowners
item.description: Flood risks have already wiped billions off the value of Australian homes, according to a new report.

item.title: Trump made no mention of them in his ceasefire address. They say violence is ongoing
item.description: While the world's focus has been on a ceasefire in Gaza, the occupied West Bank remains a flashpoint.

item.title: The cost of living crisis has financially crippled many Australians. But there's an even bigger problem
item.description: The cost of living crisis continues to affect many Australians. And the impacts are going well beyond people struggling to pay the bills.

item.title: PM says Kevin Rudd has his backing to stay on as ambassador to the US | Morning News Bulletin 22 October 2025
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says Kevin Rudd has his support to remain in the role of ambassador to the US; the US Vice president in Israel amid a still fragile ceasefire in Gaza; and in football, Sean Dyche to replace Ange Postecoglou as the manager of Nottingham Forest.

item.title: Meeting with Putin on hold to avoid 'waste of time', Trump says
item.description: Donald Trump had announced last week he and Vladimir Putin would meet soon in Hungary to try to bring the war in Ukraine to an end.

item.title: 'It's a big job': Ley backtracks on calls for Kevin Rudd to step down as US ambassador
item.description: Rudd was caught in an awkward exchange with Donald Trump on Tuesday over derogatory comments he wrote in the past about him.

item.title: Windy city: Victorians left without power and NSW heat records smashed in 'extreme' day
item.description: A heat "bubble" from the outback smashed temperature records across NSW, while damaging and destructive winds left 14,000 Victorians without power.

item.title: Sarkozy begins his prison sentence in France - still maintaining his innocence
item.description: The former President of France, Nicholas Sarkozy, has begun his 5-year prison sentence, becoming the first French leader to be jailed since World War Two. He was convicted of a criminal conspiracy to finance his election campaign with funds from a Libyan dictator. The 70 year is appealing the decision, claiming the case was politically motivated.

item.title: Breastfeeding reduces the risk of breast cancer, researchers say
item.description: Australian researchers have found breastfeeding can protect women against breast cancer by building up their immunity. According to a new study, pregnancy and breastfeeding produces infection-fighting T-cells that help guard against abnormal cells that could develop into cancer.

item.title: JD Vance says he has 'great optimism' Gaza ceasefire will hold, as more bodies returned
item.description: There has been tension over the ceasefire, with Hamas saying it needs time to find the remaining bodies of Israeli hostages.

item.title: British troops to go to Gaza | Midday News Bulletin 22 October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin ... China's urges Australia to avoid undermining relationship of both allies.. U-N says it's providing aid to displaced people in Sudan.. and in Golf, Australian women golfers eying acclaimed team title.

item.title: PM's plane makes emergency landing in US after crew member hurt
item.description: Anthony Albanese was returning from his trip to the US, where he met with US President Donald Trump.

item.title: Battlefields, boardrooms, briefing rooms: Ukraine war drags on after delays in ceasefire talks
item.description: Diplomacy has overtaken the battlefield in the Ukraine war, with Washington, Moscow, and Kyiv offering starkly different paths to peace. The Kremlin says no Trump-Putin summit date is set, while Washington insists leverage not concessions will end the war.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 October 2025
item.description: A five-minute bulletin for English Language learners

item.title: Gaza ceasefire going 'better than expected', JD Vance says on Israel trip
item.description: More than a week into the Gaza ceasefire, senior US officials have visited Israel to discuss ways to progress to the next stage of Donald Trump's 20-point peace plan. Flareups of violence in recent days has threatened to unravel the ceasefire. Meanwhile, the United Nations says it is important the ceasefire holds - to allow for aid deliveries to be scaled up in Gaza.

item.title: 'They've been great': Trump made a major concession to Australia on defence
item.description: After previously calling for more investment in defence, it appears Donald Trump has let Australia off the hook.

item.title: China dismisses criticism over conduct in South China Sea |Evening News Bulletin 22 October 2025
item.description: China's Defence Ministry dismisses Australia's criticism over military conduct in South China Sea, UN says it's providing aid to displaced people in Sudan, Geelong coach Chris Scott denies the club is struggling with star midfielder Bailey Smith's off-field behaviour

item.title: Investor warning about FOMO as gold stocks tumble
item.description: The gold price has seen its worst one day fall in 12 years as gold stocks tumble after their recent run. Similarly, rare earths also slide. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Cameron Gleeson from Betashares and Scott Phillips from The Motley Fool to find out why some investors are pressing the sell button and offers a reality check.

item.title: Australian-PNG defence treaty: 'one big fence securing two houses'
item.description: The 31st Australia-Papua New Guinea Ministerial Forum was hosted in Canberra on Monday [[Oct 20]], focusing on the implementation of the historic mutual defence treaty signed between the two countries earlier this month. The 'puk-puk' treaty will see Australia invest millions of dollars in the PNG defence force. A key part of the deal is a taskforce to recruit PNG citizens into the Australian Defence Force, but this has been criticized by former PNG defence personnel who claim the pact is harmful because PNG does not share Australia's fear of China.

item.title: Japan's first female Prime Minister: an 'Iron Lady' with tough tasks ahead
item.description: Japan's newly elected Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi has promised to "work like a horse" to get the country back on track. As the country's first female Prime Minister, Ms Takaichi will have to deal with the growing domestic dissatisfaction over economy, wages and cost of living.

item.title: Tough task for Australian women golfers
Deadly threat of homelessness
Wong says UN is in crisis
Is the gold rush losing its lustre? What to expect as prices plunge
item.description: After more than a year of rapid growth, gold experienced its biggest single-day fall in over a decade overnight.

item.title: Government has better deal for Aussie businesses
Minerals deal won't break environment rules says Watt
Japan's Sanae Takaichi makes history but will it change things for Japanese women?
item.description: Sanae Takaichi took office on Tuesday as Japan's first female prime minister but on the same day she appointed only two female ministers in a 19-member cabinet.

item.title: Boom towns: Australia's surging suburbs, record prices and Brisbane's rise to No. 2
item.description: It's been a strong quarter for the housing market, according to a new report. Find out which suburbs saw the biggest gains.

item.title: Chris was using a sunscreen while he recovered from throat cancer. Then it was recalled
item.description: More than 20 sunscreen products have been taken off Australian shelves. For the most vulnerable, it's prompted "sunscreen anxiety".

item.title: Top UN court says Israel must ease aid into Gaza to meet 'basic needs' of Palestinians
item.description: The wide-ranging ICJ ruling, quickly rejected by Israel, came as aid groups scrambled to scale up humanitarian assistance into Gaza.
